comments.text:
+5179anonymous I don't see how it's homophobic when they aren't being 
biases against an actual person that is gay. And since I've seen the 
reverse done with gay people saying gross when they are in sexual 
situations with the opposite sex. Homophobic is not wanting to be around 
gay people or making fun of gay people. It's not you as a straight person 
not wanting to be gay. Of course you wouldn't want to be gay if you're 
straight just like a gay person wouldn't want people to think they are 
straight. And even if we reverse it to be one straight woman and one 
straight man they too wouldn't want to put themselves in sexual situations 
if they are already married to someone else or are jut friends. Either way 
with any sexual orientation this scene would still be cheating because both 
characters are in a relationship with someone else. And of course they are 
going to start talking about "manly" things after that. What else is there 
to say? "We're just friends?"  No because in this point of the movie these 
two aren't even friends. They don't like each other to begin with. And 
putting your hand in someone ass is gross period.

comments.text:
+5179anonymous It's not homophobic. They are not gay, Why would they feel 
comfortable cuddling and messaging each other? Plus both men are married. 
If they enjoyed it they would be cheating on their wives. Like I said if a 
lesbian woman was cuddling and messaging a gay man the two would be like 
yuck because they aren't heterosexual and if they had husbands and wives 
they would be cheating if the enjoyed the erotic please of a message or 
kissing.

 I seen the same thing played on with gay people on sitcoms. A gay man 
kisses a woman he is like "yuck. Sorry I didn't mean to do that. You know 
I'm gay right? Purses!" It's not anti heterosexuality. It's only homophobic 
if the characters were making fun of a gay couple or if the gay character 
was seen as inferior for sexuality or his gayness was something to laugh at 
like the ending scene of Some Like It Hot where the man in drag finally 
tells the dude that wanted to marry him "I'm a man" then he response by 
saying "No body is perfect." I watched a glee episode where a gay man 
kissed a straight woman after the kiss he looks at her and says "Gee 
thanks. Now I'm 100 percent sure I'm gay." It's not heterophobic, He just 
doesn't like girls so he doesn't want to kiss girls or cuddle with her or 
anything.
comments.author: LighteningXT9

comments.text:

and during this the audience is supposed to be laughing at the familiar

comments.author: 5179anonymous

comments.text:
+LighteningXT9
nah. It's definitely homophobic humor and the 80s/90s were full of such 
gags. Like the whole episode where George was so worried about enjoying a 
massage from a male masseur on Seinfeld. It's not *just* that his hand is 
presumably between his butt cheeks, though that was what put them over the 
line, but they're both clearly disturbed by the fact that they are cuddling 
and John Candy kissed Steve Martin. They jump out of bed disgusted, yuck 
yuck yuck trying to get all of the gay off of them. And what do they do to 
that end? Start talking about sports. Yeah, because that's so manly and 
hetero it will affirm that they are both not queer.

comments.author: Stephen Phillips

comments.text:
I always understood it to be Del's hand in Neal's crotch, but since it's 
implied it could be just about anywhere in that region. Also, when you 
analyze a joke like this, it tends to kill the humor.
comments.author: jw870206

comments.text: +HyborianAge idiot. love the humor.
comments.author: Stephen Phillips

comments.text:
What are you stupid? And then then you get people like Ashley to write all 
that crap about it too?
comments.author: HyborianAge

comments.text:
Well, yes. That's the joke. The joke is that his hand isn't between two 
pillows. It's between Neal's butt cheeks. That's the joke. The humour comes 
from the sudden realisation that it's not between two pillows; it comes 
from our recognition that (a) it's gross (b) it's the kind of situation a 
married couple might end up in, but they aren't married! (c) and so it 
defies the masculine stereotype. It's actually a clever piece of writing - 
there's a precedent of male comedy duos sharing the same bed (Laurel & 
Hardy, Morcambe & Wise, Bert & Ernie etc) but this presents the same 
situation in a more realistic context. I often wonder - did John Candy 
method act this bit? Where was his hand, really?
